Problem:
Consider a linear algebra problem involving an initial matrix \u0027X\u0027. The function \u0027f(X) = e^{At}X\u0027 transforms \u0027X\u0027 over time \u0027t\u0027, where \u0027A\u0027 is a constant skew-symmetric matrix. This explores changes under the integral transformation using the Laplace Transform of \u0027X\u0027.

Can the initial matrix \u0027X_0\u0027 at time \u0027t = 0\u0027 be exactly determined from observing \u0027X(T)\u0027 at time \u0027T\u0027 without knowing if \u0027f(X)\u0027 was applied initially?
Explanation: Given the orthogonality of \u0027e^{At}\u0027 resulting from a skew-symmetric \u0027A\u0027, the original matrix \u0027X_0\u0027 can be recovered by applying the inverse transformation \u0027e^{-AT}\u0027 to \u0027X(T)\u0027. This inverse operation accurately retrieves \u0027X_0\u0027, whether or not \u0027f(X)\u0027 was initially applied.
